t: Job 29
Job’s Past Was Glorious
And*p Job again took up his discourse and said,
“Oh*pn that I were as in months gone by, As*ln in the days when God watched over me;
When*ln His lamp shone over my head, And*iln by His light I walked through darkness;
As*ln I was in the prime of my days, When*ln the friendship of God was*i over my tent;
When*ln the Almighty was yet with me, And*iln my children were around me;
When*ln my steps were bathed in butter, And*ln the rock poured out for me streams of oil!
When*ln I went out to the gate of the city, When*ln I took my seat in the square,
The*ln young men saw me and hid themselves, And*ln the old men arose and*i stood.
The*ln princes stopped talking And*ln put their*i hands on their mouths;
The*ln voice of the nobles was hushed, And*ln their tongue stuck to their palate.
For*ln when the ear heard, it called me blessed, And*ln when the eye saw, it gave witness of me,
Because*ln I delivered the poor who cried for help, And*ln the orphan who had no helper.
The*ln blessing of the one ready to perish came upon me, And*ln I made the widow’s heart sing for joy.
I*ln put on righteousness, and it clothed me; My*ln justice was like a robe and a turban.
I*ln was eyes to the blind And*ln feet to the lame.
I*ln was a father to the needy, And*ln I investigated the case which I did not know.
I*ln broke the jaws of the wicked And*ln snatched the prey from his teeth.
Then*ln I thought, ‘I shall die in my nest, And*ln I shall multiply my*i days as the sand.
My*ln root is spread out to the waters, And*ln dew lies all night on my branch.
My*ln glory is ever*i new with me, And*ln my bow is renewed in my hand.’
“To*ln me they listened and waited, And*ln kept silent for my counsel.
After*ln my words they did not speak again, And*ln my speech dropped on them.
They*ln waited for me as for the rain, And*ln opened their mouth as for the spring rain.
I*ln smiled on them when they did not believe, And*ln the light of my face they did not cast down.
I*ln chose a way for them and sat as chief, And*ln dwelt as a king among the troops, As*ln one who comforted the mourners.
